Encoding the Gettysburg Address

publicationStmt.publisher: Self-published Created as part of a class exercise

bibl.title: President Lincoln's Address at Gettysburg
bibl.publisher: San Francisco Bulletin Published as Daily Evening Bulletin

editorialDecl.p: Applause lines are labeled in this transcription. Punctuation and spellings have been maintained within the transcription. Words or phrases that are deemed indecipherable have been noted as "[illegible]," and letters that are deemed indecipherable have been noted as "_."

div.head: President Lincoln's Address at Gettysburg
div.p: The consecration of the Soldiers' Cemetery at Gettysburg, Pa. He said:

Four scores and seven years ago our fathers established upon this continent a government subscribed in liberty and dedicated to the fundamental principles that all men are created equal by a good God. [Applause] Now we are engaged in a great contest—the question whether this nation, any nation, so conceived, so educated, can long remain. We are met on a great battle-field of the war; we are met here to dedicate a portion of that field as the final resting place of those who have given their lives that the nation might live. It is all right, befitting and proper, that we should do this—but in a larger sense, we cannot dedicate—we cannot consecrate—we cannot hallow this ground. The brave and self-sacrificing men, living and dead, who struggled here, have consecrated it far above our power to add or detract. [Great applause.] The dead will little heed. Let us long remember what we have, but not forget what they did here. [Immense applause.], nor long remember, what we say here, but it can never forget It is for us the, rather—the living—to be dedicated here to the unfinished work that they have thus far so nobly carried forward. ["G__d," and great applause.]It is better for us to be dedivated to the great task remaining before us: for [illegible] to renew our devotion to that cause for which they gave the full measure of their devotion. Here let us resolve that what they have done shall not have been done in vain; that the nation shall, under God, have a new birth; and that Government of the people; founded by the people, for the people, shall not perish.
